page.title: 01ATHERSTONE/MANCETTER HISTORY
page.content: In ROMAN times,MANCETTER was a Roman military fort. There is argument that Boudiccan forces fought the Romans in the area in the last great battle.From AD100 to AD370 MANCETTER pottery became a flourishing industry over a wide area In SAXON times MANCETTER became the centre of the parish, ATHERSTONE being part of it. ATHERSTONE, probably became a focus for travellers at the crossroads of the Watling Street and the north-south route from Derby to Oxford. It was only 8 miles from Tamworth where the Saxon King of Mercia had his palace. In NORMAN times there is an entry in the Domesday Book- "The Countess (Lady Godiva) herself held in Aderstone 3 hides for 5 ploughs. 11 villagers, 2 smallholders and 1 slave with 4 ploughs Meadow 6 acres: Woodland 2 leagues long and 2 leagues wide." Value 40s in 1066.
